data.text: Is It Easier to Ride a Gravel Bike than a Mountain Bike?

Is a gravel bike easier to ride than a mountain bike? After doing 40 miles on my mountain bike i wondered if it would be easier on a different bike; like less wide tires and less friction? Update: the mountain bike I used is an aluminum Jamis Divide T6 hardtail with 27.5x2.25" tires. Pretty much all stock.
Depends on what you are riding. Gravel/pavement, heck yes.
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: that is what i was wondering. Thank you
data.author: Meghan Marie

data.text: narrower tire, higher pressure, sometimes a larger diameter tire. So yes, it can be easier to ride a gravel bike 40 miles on-road than a mountain bike.
data.author: Teeb Moots

data.text: Yes almost certainly if it is terrain that suits a gravel bike.
data.author: Cory Anderson

data.text: Probably also depends on what your mtb is and what tires you have on it‚Ä¶ if you have a trek supercaliber or something then a cheap gravel bike probably isn‚Äôt faster. But considering the differences I see between my ‚Äòmtb gravel‚Äô (more upright and wider tires) and my ‚Äòroad gravel‚Äô (better frame, better wheels, slightly more aero, 38mm slicks) then I wouldn‚Äôt consider bringing my mtb on gravel
data.author: Neil Wortley

data.text: Gotta say, I prefer my gravel bike. I've ridden mountain bikes and they just don't feel good after long hours in the saddle.
data.author: Charlene Randle

data.text: My gravel bike has MTB tires. The riding position and drop bars are better for longer gravel rides. My MTBs are set up for trail riding (short stem, tall wide bars).
data.author: Philip Rohrer

data.text: It the terrain is gravel / dirt road yes a gravel bike will be faster

data.text: Mountain biking is a sport, graveling is a lifestyle! Lol

data.text: Get a set of 700x35 gravelking SS for more road conditions and a mtb tire on 650b rims for the rough terrain.
data.author: Matthew Robinson

data.text: Not so much due to the width of tires. Just bike and tire design.
data.author: Nick Little

data.text: Well‚Ä¶there‚Äôs a lot to consider. I recently did a gravel event and 2nd place in the 62 mile route with a full suspension MTB. So I‚Äôm your case are we talking carbon frame, full suspension XC bike or alloy trail bike? 2.0 tires, 2.8 tires? Etc. I enjoy riding my SS MTB more even long distance but I was definitely faster/more efficient when I had a drop bar geared gravel bike. ‚ÄúGravel‚Äù here involves wash board roads, sand, golf ball sized caliche rocks, gravel, chip seal pavement. 29x2.0 is the smallest/skinniest I‚Äôll go.
data.author: Matt Evans

data.text: gravel here is clinker (mostly incorrectly called scoria), cattle guards, what felt like mini pumptrack. My tires are 27.5x2.25. And its a aluminum hard tail.
data.author: Meghan Marie

data.text:
I saw your update including the bike specs. Are you good with changing out your own tires and what not? I recently threw some 27.5x1.5 gravel tires on my wife‚Äôs full suspension for here and she said it made a huge difference in how easy it is to pedal. She went from a 26x2.3 down to a 27.5x1.5(new wheel too). Same rolling diameter roughly but pedaled way easier. You trade some grip and stability for efficiency. Anyhow, a set of this was like $50-70 from Amazon, if you are good with your own bike work buy a set and throw them on your bike and see. It‚Äôs a cheap way to see if you feel the difference or not. These are what I got her. Maxxis Rambler 27.5x1.50 Adult Unisex Tyre, Black https://www.amazon.com/dp/B078WFPV6M/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_api_i_XRNYN7T9DYCV8W01Z6VC
Maxxis Rambler 27.5x1.50 Adult Unisex Tyre, Black
amazon.com
data.author: Matt Evans

data.text: You will cover more miles on the gravel bike
data.author: Luke Derstein

data.text: NOPE.
data.author: Levi Turner

data.text: In my opinion long rides are definitely better on a drop bar bikes. Longer, faster, more efficient. When I rode MTBs 30 kilometers was a long ride. On the gravel bike my rides average more like 45 to 80 kilometers of singletrack and fireroads. Just match your bike, wheels and tires to the conditions üêç
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: It depends on the MTB and the terrain. A light fast XC race bike will outclimb and in most cases just be outright faster off-road even on gravel tracks once the trail surface gets even a little bit chunky. Now of course if we're talking about a full suspension gravel bike, it "can" close the distance, and when the road surface is smooth be faster, but the only two areas really seperating the two is the tires being used and the (typically) higher gearing on the gravel bike. Otherwise, I am fairly confident that the MCR is heavier than my ProCaliber w/ XO1 and carbon wheels. Riding long distances on a MTB just requires some clever additions like running bar-ends inboard which provides a pretty decent hood position and a lockout on the fork. If you're only doing gravel, tires like the Vittoria Terreno XC, Hutchinson Skeleton or Schawlbe Thunder Burts are quite fast on road and off. They're just not going to be suited for technical singletrack without some finesse. As far as the distance, it just depends on the person, terrain and bike....my afterwork quick training ride is 30k which is a bit of climbing, forest/farm road doubletrack, cobbles and a few slivers of technical singletrack. I am faster on my MTB especially when the cobbles (big gnarly things), farm doubletrack and technical bits. My average speed is 22-24km/h.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: did you miss the part where I said ‚Äúin my opinion‚Äù? My ‚Äúlight‚Äù MCR weighs in at 9.86kg with pedals, dropper post, pump, F&R lockout, 3 bottle cages and Ultradynamico 700 x 42mm Cava Race tires. Knock off 120g for the 2.0‚Äù Furious Freds and that puts it at 9.74kg. My ‚Äúheavy‚Äù MCR with an 80mm front fork, all the same extras and 27.5‚Äù x 2.2‚Äù rear, 2.3‚Äù front comes in right at 11kg. A BIG difference in pedaling efficiency, weight transfer, and ‚Äúgoing the distance‚Äù is the drop bar riding position. I have much better power transfer with my weight over my legs and is more aerodynamic, which really makes a difference over 35kph when riding between different trail systems on big rides. Also in the case of the MCR it has really long chainstays (440mm) making it easier to transfer weight to the front wheel. Having 4 sets of wheels and dozens of tires I‚Äôm all about matching tires and wheels to the ride. It‚Äôs not about the speed for me. It‚Äôs more of one big adventure after another. Again, that‚Äôs just ‚Äúmy opinion‚Äù üêç https://strava.app.link/wBkVQH0NDqb
data.author: Mark Jake Jacobson

data.text: It really just depends on the mountain bike, the fit, the setup and the type of gravel, but typically a gravel bike will be faster and more efficient. No matter what you do, if you have a trail MTB or long travel....basically anything more than a 100mm XC bike and running wide bars, a Gravel bike will be faster....but you didn't state what MTB you have. I have a Trek ProCaliber with bar-ends ran in-board for a psudo-hood position and the only bit that actually makes it slower is the tires, but the only place that the gravel bike is faster is if I'm including road sections on the ride. If its off-road, I'd say they're equal but the moment it gets less smooth, ruts or cobbles.....the MTB is quite a bit faster.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: i have a Jamis Divide T6. Everything is stock. I love the fact that it is super fast down hills but wonder if there is a better bike for next time i gravel race.
data.author: Meghan Marie

data.text: Tires and gearing are the biggest differences between a fast XC MTB and a 'massive' tire clearance gravel bike. Sure one has dropbars and one is flatbars, but the geometries will largely perform about the same...it just depends on what the manufacture wants and what performance metrics they're trying to achieve. As far as how it translates for you, it really depends on your experience and fitness level, but also the environment you're going to be riding the bike....if it's all mixed with road sections, techy MTB sections, long grinding climbs and fast punchy climbs where you're going to basically throw every type of situation at a bike and the rider on the course....a HT MTB is going to win out.....its just more versatile. For a gravel bike to win out, you have to kick out the distance further on tamer terrain and keep the type of terrain relatively consistent. Also, it depends on what type of gravel race: Is it a multi-day unsupported race or a one-day variable length 40/60/100miler. In the end, its a different tool for a bit different purpose. Of course there's more overlap than comparing a MTB to a road bike, but they're going to be faster in different areas. Also tire selection is a HUGE factor. You really need to know what the terrain is you're riding, and use the right tire for the situation.....or something that is versatile enough to be fast where you need it and grippy when you need it. The difference between dropbars and flatbars is a lesser point of interest, and really comes down to personal preference. In general though, you're going to get more value for your dollar with a flatbar bike than a dropbar bike, and a flatbar bike will be more versatile, but the things that a gravel bike does better and how it fits into the market, it does extremely good up to it's limitations. I know I'm not really speaking in absolutes. That is because there is more variables and caveats that muddy the decision-making process. I can only speak on what I do and the experience I have: I ride/race MTB both XC and Enduro. I ride/race gravel. I ride and do club-sponsored one-day classics which covers most of the huge 1-day classics here in Belgium in road biking. I do a bit of bikepacking, but they are usually weekend get-a-ways. I own 3 gravel bikes 3 MTBs and 2 road bikes....also use to be a mechanic in a previous life......I believe I can say that I know my way around bikes.
data.author: Josh Kebschull
